fields.title: Blue intensifying focus on secured lending
fields.content: Swimming upstream with other banks all clamouring for unsecured credit market.

fields.title: Investec to grow African assets to $45bn
fields.content: Helped partly by growing demand for the continent's debt.

fields.title: Thousands of financial advisors still to write exam
fields.content: There might not be enough exam dates and slots left to accommodate everyone.

fields.title: Blue CEO wary of SA unsecured market
fields.content: Boss of pan-African lender weighs in on bubble debate, forecasts “correction”.

fields.title: Old Mutual flinches
fields.content: If you buy them now, you miss R2.24 of dividends but there will be fewer shares in issue.

fields.title: FSB refers Absa case to enforcement committee
fields.content: ABSA Asset Management admitted the contraventions and agreed to settle the matter.

fields.title: Standard Bank won’t rule out acquisitions to expand in Angola
fields.content: As it seeks to become one of the top five banks in the country.

fields.title: Liberty Holdings climbs to record
fields.content: Shares gain 1.5%.

fields.title: PSG Konsult HEPS up 21.6%
fields.content: Declares a final dividend of 7.3c per share.

fields.title: Absa's substantial Barclays dividend payment
fields.content: Barclays has received almost 40% of its Absa purchase price back.

fields.title: Absa Capital arranges $115m financing for MultiChoice
fields.content: As the sole bookrunner.

fields.title: Standard Bank’s new small business offering
fields.content: It believes providing banking for these businesses will be a profitable.

fields.title: PODCAST: Free data and cheaper iPads
fields.content: Are these innovations actually contributing to the bank’s business? FNB's CEO talks to Moneyweb.

fields.title: Standard Bank sells 53% of Turkish unit
fields.content: As it focuses on markets closer to home.

fields.title: FNB plans R2bn investment
fields.content: To expand in South Africa and Africa.

fields.title: RMB to sell stocks
fields.content: May cut staff to boost returns.

fields.title: Firstrand appoints global markets unit head
fields.content: Names C.J. Giddy and Pierre Joubert as joint heads.

fields.title: Absa to offer cash-back bonus in personal loans
fields.content: The bank is in a drive to get a bigger slice of unsecured lending market.

fields.title: Mantashe criticises Nedbank chairman
fields.content: Says he is trying to deflect attention away from himself.

fields.title: Winners and losers in bank market share
fields.content: As advertising reaches fever pitch who has come out on top?

fields.title: Gold One to acquire Pamodzi Gold ops
fields.content: JSE-listed gold exploration and mining companies Gold One and Goliath Gold  have entered into an agreement with the liquidators of Pamodzi Gold, to acquire the embattled mining company's assets in the East Rand.

fields.title: JSE loses three hours to connectivity issues
fields.content: The JSE has lost three hours of trading time on the equity markets due to network connectivity issues.

fields.title: Fight against corruption at crucial point
fields.content: South Africa deserves to have the best possible machinery in its fight against corruption, says Advocate Paul Hoffman, director of the Institute for Accountability in Southern Africa and senior counsel for Hugh Glenister.

fields.title: What government wants from SA mining (Video)
fields.content: Speaking at the 9th International Mining History Congress at Gold Reef City, Deputy President  Kgalema Motlanthe  outlined what government wants from South African mining going forward and revealed the intention behind the formation of the state-owned mining company.  Recorded and edited by  Michael Bratt

fields.title: February retail sales up 7.2%, above expectations
fields.content: South African retail trade sales at constant (2008) prices for February recorded a 7.2% growth year on year after an upwardly revised 4.2% [3.9%] growth in January, figures released on Wednesday by Statistics SA showed.

fields.title: Net foreign bond buying most since 2008
fields.content: Foreigners bought a net R7.79 billion worth of SA bonds on Tuesday April 17, which was the largest daily net foreign buying since 2008.

fields.title: SA inflation momentum moves above 6% level
fields.content: Inflation momentum as measured by the quarter-on-quarter annualised rate moved above the 6% level to 6.3% in March from 4.4% in February and 4.2% in January.

fields.title: Residential property market deflating: Absa
fields.content: The average value of homes in the South African residential property market is deflating and if the trend continues, nominal and real price deflation for the year is a strong possibility, Absa said on Wednesday.

fields.title: BHP Billiton reports solid nine-month production
fields.content: Resources giant BHP Billiton has reported solid production figures for the nine months ended March 2012, with production records at two of the group's high value, export orientated energy coal operations - New South Wales Energy Coal (Australia) and Cerrejon Coal (Colombia).

fields.title: FNB begins Indian operations
fields.content: FNB on Wednesday became the first African bank to launch operations in India, when it opened its first branch in Mumbai, to provide retail and commercial products and services.

fields.title: Green economy presents risks, opportunities - Anglo
fields.content: The green economy presents both risks and opportunities for resources companies, says Samantha Hoe-Richardson, group head of sustainable development and energy at Anglo American.

fields.title: Standard Bank in restructuring drive in Brazil
fields.content: Standard Bank Group's Corporate and Investment Banking business operations in Brazil, Banco Standard de Investimentos SA, on Wednesday commenced a restructuring exercise.

fields.title: Pick n Pay headline earnings down 15.1% to 160.78c
fields.content: Retailer Pick n Pay on Wednesday reported headline earnings per share of 160.78 cents for the year ended February 2012, a decrease of 15.1%.

fields.title: Online shopping on the up in SA: MasterCard survey
fields.content: Online shopping has increased significantly in SA and continues to show potential for growth, with price, convenience and security key factors to consider when making a purchasing decision, MasterCard said on Wednesday.

fields.title: Acceleration in house price growth in Q1: FNB
fields.content: There was an acceleration in house price growth in almost all segments of the market when segmented by room number and title deed in the first quarter of 2012, says John Loos, Household Sector and Property Strategist at FNB.

fields.title: Fifth consecutive month of house price growth:ooba
fields.content: Property prices showed positive year-on-year growth of 1.6% in March, as well as positive month-on-month growth of 0.7%, making this the fifth consecutive month ooba has recorded an increase in residential property prices.

fields.title: Swiss extend Iran sanctions, exempts central bank
fields.content: Switzerland has extended financial sanctions against Iran but stopped short of freezing the assets of Iran's central bank and imposing an oil embargo, pointing to an emerging policy rift with other Western powers over Tehran's nuclear ambitions.

fields.title: China sees first house price fall on year since curbs
fields.content: China's average new home price fell last month from a year earlier, the first decline in two years, raising investors' hopes that property calming policies may soon be eased.

fields.title: EU Commission: expect Spain to implement stability law quickly
fields.content: The European Commission said on Wednesday it expects Spain to take quick action to implement its stability law, with regional finances crucial to the country's fiscal strategy.

fields.title: Nestle near buying Pfizer's baby formula - sources
fields.content: Nestle, the world's biggest food group, is closing in on a deal to buy Pfizer's infant nutrition business for up to $10 billion to boost its business in China and extend its lead in the world of formula milk for babies, sources familiar with the matter said on Wednesday.

fields.title: JGBs slip slightly as Europe debt fears ease, for now
fields.content: Japanese government bond prices edged down on Wednesday, as some investors took profits with the benchmark yield wallowing near a 17-month low, and as easing fears about Europe's debt crisis whetted investors' appetite for risk.

fields.title: UK minister sued for sending Libyan back to torture
fields.content: A Libyan military commander is suing former British foreign minister Jack Straw for authorising his illegal transfer to Libya where he faced years of torture in Muammar Gaddafi's prisons, a lawyer for the commander said on Wednesday.

fields.title: Pick n Pay to enter DRC, Malawi
fields.content: South African retailer Pick n Pay will enter the Democratic Republic of Congo and Malawi in the next 12 months, its chairman said, as the merchant stretches its presence on the continent.

fields.title: West Africa cotton output seen up 29 percent in 2012/13
fields.content: West African cotton growers forecast a 29 percent increase in output to 1,738,500 tonnes for the 2012/13 season from 1,346,941 tonnes in 2011/12, data collected from cotton producers and compiled by Reuters showed on Wednesday.

fields.title: Shell looks at $4b in possible projects in nigeria
fields.content: Officials with Royal Dutch Shell PLC say they are looking at possible onshore investments in Nigeria that could be worth about $4 billion.

fields.title: Kenya gets $111m, good marks from IMF
fields.content: The International Monetary Fund on Tuesday approved a $111 million loan for Kenya, praising the country's efforts to reform its economy.

fields.title: European shares retreat
fields.content: European shares fell, with ACS leading construction stocks lower after the sale of its stake in Iberdrola.

fields.title: 'Ghost bidding not the norm’
fields.content: The SA Institute of Auctioneers (Saia) has denied a claim by former Auction Alliance chief Rael Levitt that “ghost bidding” is a  common practice in the industry.

fields.title: Bank of England to halt money-printing press
fields.content: The Bank of England is poised to turn off its money-printing press next month.

fields.title: ‘Glencore signs $6bn merger loan’
fields.content: Commodities trader Glencore signed a $6 billion syndicated loan backing its $90 billion merger with miner Xstrata.

fields.title: SA retail sales at 7.2%
fields.content: Growth in South Africa's retail sales jumped to 7.2 percent on an annual basis at constant prices in February from a revised 4.2 percent in January.

fields.title: JSE off best in trade-interrupted day
fields.content: The JSE was off its best levels shortly after midday in what has been a trade interrupted morning on the local bourse.

fields.title: Apple iPad to arrive in 12 more countries
fields.content: Apple said it would start marketing its new iPad in South Korea and 11 other countries.

fields.title: Portugal's PM: no guarantees of return to markets
fields.content: Portuguese Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho said there were “no guarantees” that the country would meet its commitment to return to the international capital markets before September 2013.

fields.title: Shell mulls $4bn in Nigerian projects
fields.content: Officials with Royal Dutch Shell PLC say they are looking at possible onshore investments in Nigeria that could be worth about $4 billion.

fields.title: Gold eases for fourth day
fields.content: Gold eased, having fallen for the past three trading days, as the euro came under pressure.

fields.title: Inflation returns to target range in March
fields.content: INFLATION fell to its lowest level in six months in March, backing the view that price pressures may be more muted than anticipated and fanning speculation that interest rates will remain steady this year.

fields.title: Gold One and Goliath Gold to buy Pamodzi’s Grootvlei assets
fields.content: GOLD One and Goliath Gold, both headed by Neal Froneman, have conditionally agreed to buy the liquidated Pamodzi Gold Grootvlei assets for R70m, bringing to an end the shameful saga that unfolded when the assets were managed Aurora Empowerment Systems.

fields.title: Pick n Pay full-year profit falls 15%
fields.content: SOUTH African food retailer Pick n Pay reported a 15% fall in full-year profit on Wednesday, missing expectations, hit by costs related to its shopper loyalty programme and investments in its supply chain.

fields.title: Retail sales jump 7,2% in February
fields.content: GROWTH in South Africa’s retail sales jumped to 7,2% on an annual basis at constant prices in February from a revised 4,2% in January, Statistics South Africa said on Wednesday.

fields.title: Acting police chief faces MPs’ ire over Mdluli
fields.content: Under a barrage of angry questions from MPs yesterday, acting national police commissioner Nhlanhla Mkhwanazi revealed that there was still an ongoing investigation into allegations of fraud against crime intelligence head Richard Mdluli.

fields.title: Delay in Diepsloot water questioned
fields.content: A PLAN to fix the sewage-polluted water supply in Diepsloot will be made public today, says the City of Johannesburg.

fields.title: Hlophe case to be dealt with under amended act
fields.content: THE complaints before the Judicial Service Commission (JSC) involving Western Cape Judge President John Hlophe will be dealt with under the amended Judicial Service Commission Act, said spokesman CP Fourie on Wednesday.

fields.title: State’s R3bn office leases bill ‘too high’ — Treasury
fields.content: The government spends an astonishing R3bn a year leasing properties for its departments — a figure that is rising rapidly and which the Treasury says is far too high.

fields.title: Another blow as Malema’s appeal fails
fields.content: EMBATTLED African National Congress (ANC) Youth League president Julius Malema was dealt another blow yesterday when his appeal against an immediate suspension was dismissed by the party’s national disciplinary committee of appeals.

fields.title: Cracks in league may trip Malema
fields.content: GROWING divisions within the African National Congress (ANC) Youth League could weigh heavily on the league’s expelled president, Julius Malema, when he files heads of argument against his expulsion before the ANC appeals committee today.

fields.title: Cosatu to embark on national strike against e-tolls
fields.content: THE battle against tolling Gauteng’s highways escalated yesterday when the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) announced another national strike and the possibility of a court challenge against the contentious system.

fields.title: MP wants SA black doctoral students helped
fields.content: SA is not doing enough to "grow its own timber" and support black local doctoral and post-doctoral students, says higher education and training portfolio committee chairman Ishmael Malale.

fields.title: Expert backs plans for  OR Tambo aerotropolis
fields.content: PLANS to make OR Tambo International Airport Africa’s first aerotropolis received a boost on Tuesday with an international airport development expert endorsing a proposal to make strategic use of the airport along with the land surrounding it.

fields.title: Who pays for infrastructure and a greener SA?
fields.content: TOM Plaistowe is portfolio manager at Old Mutual Investment Group South Africa (Omigsa) alternative investments.

fields.title: Shale gas - Hold the fracking licence
fields.content: As the debate on fracking for shale gas in the Karoo intensifies, SA is waiting to see if the moratorium on exploration first imposed in April 2011 will be lifted.

fields.title: Medical aid - Lawyers to challenge schemes over expenses  recovered from Road Accident Fund
fields.content: Is it right that your medical scheme can request repayment of medical expenses recovered from your Road Accident Fund  (RAF) claim?

fields.title: Tech review - HP Z workstation
fields.content: A few years ago, when laptops and  netbooks were all the rage, tech experts  predicted the death of the PC as the  business world moved towards a mobile  environment.

fields.title: Q & A - Kopano Ke Matla’s investment in Raubex
fields.content: Raubex commercial & financial director  Francois Diedrechsen spoke to Razina  Munshi about Cosatu investment arm  Kopano Ke Matla’s stake in Raubex

fields.title: Where are they now? - Stephen Beesley
fields.content: Former BP SA and BP Africa CEO  Stephen Beesley had been retired for  about a year when his old company  offered him a project that turned out to  be bitter-sweet.

fields.title: Agri business - BKB  proposed buying out KLK
fields.content: The consolidation of the local agri- business sector continues apace, with  news last week that Port Elizabeth-based  BKB has proposed buying out KLK,  which is located in Upington.

fields.title: Entrepreneur - Tony Lovegrove
fields.content: After watching a caddy removing a pin  during a PGA golf tournament on  television, Tony Lovegrove turned to a  friend and remarked that the pin was  the perfect advertising spot because the cameras were focused on it and  millions of viewers were watching.

fields.title: Another Week - 13 April 2012
fields.content: British prime minister David Cameron meets with Japanese prime minister Yoshihiko Noda in Tokyo on Tuesday.

fields.title: Deal of the week - Molson Coors & StarBev
fields.content: Global beer market consolidation has  taken another big step forward with  Molson Coors’ acquisition of Czech Republic brewer StarBev from UK private  equity firm CVC Capital Partners.

fields.title: SA tractors sales climb
fields.content: SA farmers bought more new  tractors this February than they  have in the same month for the  past 30 years.

fields.title: Boom time for Africa’s passenger air traffic
fields.content: Africa’s passenger air traffic will  soar from 68m to 150m by 2030,  predicts the Air Transport Action  Group.

fields.title: Pharmaceuticals companies good news
fields.content: The pharmaceutical industry in SA has seen some bad days but business is moving north apace.

fields.title: Sovereign debt ratings
fields.content: The demand for products that look at the debt ratings of countries has come from global responsible investors.

fields.title: Ububele loses appetite
fields.content: Ububele has indicated a willingness to expand its ice cream making  facilities by opening plants in Durban and Cape Town in a bid to  secure retail business

fields.title: Vodacom’s African nightmare
fields.content: It’s not going too well for the company in the Democratic  Republic of Congo (DRC), where it has been charged in the commercial court  and could lose the shares it holds.

fields.title: 1Time strains
fields.content: Long-serving 1time Holdings CEO Glenn Orsmond departed  suddenly in September; then in March 1time Airlines CEO Rodney James quit

fields.title: New listings
fields.content: A flurry of new  listings may not be  far off so investors  had best be  prepared.

fields.title: Telkom lawyers on speed-dial
fields.content: Emerging market rules lead to more open interpretation and more court battles.

fields.title: Currency trading lure
fields.content: An explosion of interest sees retail investors and others currency trading in their hundreds.

fields.title: Executive pay slowdown
fields.content: As top companies feel the economic pinch, some executives are trimming their take home pay

fields.title: Wonderful weekend with Mark Cutifani
fields.content: Australian-born  Mark Cutifani, CEO  of AngloGold  Ashanti since 2007,  talks to Charlotte Mathews.

fields.title: Game review - Fifa Street 4
fields.content: Fifa and EA Games’ new Fifa Street 4 brings speed and realism to the franchise.

fields.title: Cycling - Absa Cape Epic mountain- bike race
fields.content: The eight-day Absa Cape Epic mountain- bike race, which ended last week, covered 781km and climbed 16300m.  Max Gebhardt survived to tell the tale.

fields.title: Game review - Tiger Woods PGA Tour 13
fields.content: One interesting feature in the game mode is called "Legacy Challenge", where you take control of Woods in the various stages of his career.

fields.title: Seven questions - 2012  Epic
fields.content: Kevin Evans, of team 360Life,  second in this year’s Absa Cape Epic with partner David George.

fields.title: Cinema - The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel
fields.content: With its perfect  cast, this tale of  retired folk  returning to India is an unmissable film  in its niche.

fields.title: Book of the week - Eight Days in September
fields.content: The schadenfreude with which SA’s  chattering classes greeted the summary ejection of Thabo Mbeki from the presidency in September 2008  helped to obscure an important issue.

fields.title: Books review - Uncommon Service
fields.content: In a global economy where service  industries dominate, you’d think companies would understand the concept  of service.

fields.title: Food for thought - A fine meal and a good  time
fields.content: We felt rich  and invincible, almost as though we worked for  Goldman Sachs and called our investors  muppets.

fields.title: Rugby - Can Stormers keep going?
fields.content: The absurdity of the Super Rugby  league format was demonstrated again  after last weekend’s matches.

fields.title: Auctions body denies ghost bids a norm
fields.content: The SA Institute of Auctioneers has refuted a claim by disgraced Auctions Alliance chief Rael Levitt that ghost bidding is common in the industry.

fields.title: Retail sales see unexpected surge
fields.content: Retail sales jumped to 7.2% in February compared to year ago, indicating a healthy pick-up in consumer spending.

fields.title: CCMA sees jump in use of services
fields.content: The Commission for Conciliation, Mediation, and Arbitration has seen a significant rise in its involvement in public interest disputes, says director Nerine Kahn.

fields.title: Consumer inflation slows again
fields.content: SA's consumer price index was down to 6.0% in March, bringing it back within the Reserve Bank's target range.

fields.title: Argentine seizure scuppers Chinese deal
fields.content: A move by Buenos Aires to nationalise energy firm YPF, a division of Spain's Repsol, has hampered a plan by China's Sinopec to buy YPF.

fields.title: Too much spent on state leases - report
fields.content: The National Treasury is concerned that the R3bn a year spent on leasing properties for state departments is too high, a report says.

fields.title: Pick n Pay posts drop in profit
fields.content: Pick n Pay has reported a 15% fall in full-year profit, missing expectations as it is hit by shopper loyalty programme costs and supply chain investments.

fields.title: Bailout for Spain inevitable - experts
fields.content: Economic experts are unsure how much money will be needed or precisely when, but some are near certain that Spain will eventually seek a multi-billion euro bailout.

fields.title: Engen turns to Saudi for crude
fields.content: Engen, SA's biggest buyer of Iranian crude, is replacing imports from the Islamic Republic with additional crude from top oil exporter Saudi Aramco, trade sources say.

fields.title: IMF: SA sputters, African growth robust
fields.content: SA's growth will continue to lag while high commodity prices will boost the rest of the continent, says the International Monetary Fund.

fields.title: Engen buys Saudi oil to replace Iran's shortfall
fields.content: Trade sources say Engen has decided to buy additional crude from top oil exporter Saudi Aramco after it halted imports from Iran.

fields.title: Pick n Pay's full-year profits fail to meet expectations
fields.content: Pick n Pay has reported a15% fall in full-year profit, hit by costs related to his shopper loyalty programme and investment sin its supply chain.

fields.title: Warren Buffett reveals prostate cancer condition
fields.content: Berkshire Hathaway chief executive Warren Buffett has revealed he has stage one prostate cancer, adding his condition was not life-threatening.

fields.title: Motlanthe points at need for mining intervention
fields.content: Deputy President Kgalema Motlanthe says the recent global financial crisis has shown that more state intervention is needed in the mining industry.

fields.title: IMF warns countries to avoid climbing debt
fields.content: The IMF has issued a call to bickering US politicians, urging them to solve the country's debt problems before the vulnerable economy is tipped over.

fields.title: Business Unity SA calls for e-toll delay
fields.content: Business Unity South Africa says the launch of the e-tolling system on April 30 must be delayed until all public concerns have been addressed.

fields.title: British panel rules 'fracking' can continue
fields.content: A British government-appointed panel has said fracking should resume under strict conditions, though it would probably trigger earthquakes.

fields.title: Google fined $25 000 for Street View data collection
fields.content: Google has been ordered to pay $25 000 for collecting personal information without permission and not cooperating with an investigation into it.

fields.title: Korean-American Kim chosen to lead World Bank
fields.content: The World Bank has chosen Jim Yong Kim as its next chief in a decision that surprised few despite the first-ever challenge to the US.

fields.title: Nigerian candidate bemoans World Bank post
fields.content: Nigerian Finance Minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala says the World Bank appointment is not being decided on merit and that the US nominee will win.

fields.title: Gordhan questions World Bank election process
fields.content: Serious doubt exists about the transparency of the process in electing the next World Bank president, Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan said.

fields.title: Rwanda's urban inflation driven higher by food prices
fields.content: The consumer price index for urban areas in Rwanda has risen by almost 3% due and this has been attributed partly to higher food prices.

fields.title: Angolan officials admit to hiding Cobalt shares
fields.content: Three of Angola's most powerful officials have acknowledged they hold concealed shares in an oil venture linked to Cobalt International Energy.

fields.title: Total close down Nigerian gas plant after leak
fields.content: Oil company Total has shut down a gas plant in Nigeria after a gas leak and has begun working at trying to limit the environmental impact.

fields.title: The economic week ahead: Pain in Spain
fields.content: Fears are mounting Spain might be headed for a bailout, while eyes will also be on a series of corporate earnings reports and data releases elsewhere.

fields.title: Nigerian militants threaten to attack SA investments
fields.content: Nigerian militant organisation Mend has threatened to attack SA investments, including MTN, unless their leader, Henry Okah, is released.

fields.title: Community papers a battlefield
fields.content: Opposition to the merger of The Witness and Media24 has shed light on shady practices in the community newspaper sector.

fields.title: Motlanthe laments pace of infrastructure development
fields.content: Deputy President Kgalema Motlanthe says the pace of infrastructure development is lagging behind what the country needs to evolve.

fields.title: SA economy showing signs of stability
fields.content: Treasury's Lungisa Fuzile says the economy is on a more sure footing but the target growth of 7% will not come without fixing infrastructure backlogs.

fields.title: Zimbabwe turns to market financing to boost farmers
fields.content: Economically-ravaged Zimbabwe has started plans to longer subsidise farmers, even though its population is facing starvation.

fields.title: Shareholder revolt rocks Turkcell
fields.content: Turkcell's internal strife has the potential to play into the hands of South African cellphone giant MTN, which is tied to its corruption case.

fields.title: Taxes force start-ups underground
fields.content: Statistics have shown a slump in the establishment of new businesses, but experts say they have just gone under the radar.

fields.title: Bold bid to win a bigger slice
fields.content: Bidvest Bank says its decision to cap fees at R72 a month does not signal a price war with the big four banks in South Africa.

fields.title: Icasa fails consumers, report says
fields.content: Namibia has been held up as an example of how a regulator can stop cellphone giants from making a killing and ripping off customers.

fields.title: Transnet reveals mega upgrade
fields.content: Although it has been described as 'conservative', Transnet's mooted infrastructure upgrade will create jobs, increase exports and meet local demands.

fields.title: Reserve Bank's Holocaust denier
fields.content: Stephen Goodson has been on the South African Reserve Bank's board from 2003. He holds extremist views on Hitler's Germany and Gaddafi's Libya.

fields.title: Apple, publishers sued for e-book price fixing
fields.content: Apple and five publishers have been sued by the United States's justice department for conspiring to fix the prices of e-books.

fields.title: Standard Bank sees rapid branch growth in Angola
fields.content: The head of Standard Bank's Angolan unit is targeting explosive growth in the country by quadrupling its branch network there by the end of the year.

fields.title: Trade conditions turn favourable in March
fields.content: Trade conditions continued to improve in March after moving into positive territory in February, as reflected in the Trade Activity Index from Sacci.

fields.title: US union lent a hand in Walmart battle
fields.content: According to reports, a US union paid legal fees for a local union to fight US retail giant Walmart's acquisition of local retailer Massmart.

fields.title: FNB accused of covering up fraud syndicate
fields.content: A Jo'burg entrepreneur has accused FNB of covering up fraudulent misrepresentation by one of its officials in a transaction that cost him R1.3-milion.

fields.title: Anglo, De Beers to hammer out merger
fields.content: The Competition Tribunal is expected to hear the case for the proposed merger between giants Anglo American PLC and De Beers South Africa today.

fields.title: SA's economy dependent on entrepreneurs
fields.content: Employment has grown marginally in South Africa but analysts warn the slowing of small business activity could lead to economic stagnation.

fields.title: Standard Bank slashes stake in Turkey's Unlu
fields.content: Standard Bank says it will reduce its stake in Turkish venture Standard Unlu, the  latest move by the lender to scale back non-African operations.

fields.title: Web giants pander to Chinese government
fields.content: China's largest internet companies have promised the government they will banish online rumours after whispers of a coup swept through the country.

fields.title: Rail boost 'to create 588 000 new jobs in seven years'
fields.content: Transnet says it will create 588 000 new jobs in seven years by spending R300-billion on shifting SA's freight focus from roads to rail.

fields.title: Transnet to boost coal, iron ore rail capacity
fields.content: Plans to increase Transnet's capacity to haul iron ore from mines to ports by 56% over the next seven years are in the works, says CEO Brian Molefe.

fields.title: Glencore and Xstrata merger eyed with suspicion
fields.content: Ivan Glasenberg and Mick Davis are expected to begin global tour to coax shareholders into accepting their proposed £23-billion merger deal.

fields.title: World Bank needs refocusing, says Nigerian contender
fields.content: Nigeria's Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala says the World Bank needs a shake-up to end the inertia that has built up over six decades.

fields.title: The economic week ahead: Short but sweet?
fields.content: The economic calendar has lightened due to the holidays, but a few key events will still keep investors on their toes when trading resumes.

fields.title: Zim minister: Foreigners' mines won't be nationalised
fields.content: Zimbabwe will not nationalise foreign mining companies that haven't yet ceded a 5% stake to locals, the country's economic planning minister says.

fields.title: Who says print is dead?
fields.content: Far from killing off printing, the rise of mobile devices and apps may just turn out to be its saving grace.

fields.title: E-toll vehicle impounding 'not true', says Sanral
fields.content: The South African National Roads Agency has refuted media reports about the impounding of vehicles where a road user has outstanding e-toll fees.

fields.title: Cosatu doubts effectiveness of strike ballots
fields.content: Cosatu in the Western Cape says re-introducing a labour law that requires unions to conduct ballots before strikes would not solve violent acts.

fields.title: Vision of the future takes shape
fields.content: South Africa's national development plan and the ANC's proposals have people talking, although the proposal is still a draft document.

fields.title: The big fuel squeeze is here
fields.content: Sanctions on Iran have pushed up the oil price, but government’s levies and tariffs are not easing the pain as massive fuel price hikes hit consumers.

fields.title: Sasol's plans to quit Iran under way
fields.content: With MTN refusing to pull out of Iran, Sasol has stopped buying Iranian crude oil in a move to exit the Islamic republic.

fields.title: Row over new securities tax
fields.content: Analysts have claimed that billions are at stake and the derivatives market could be destroyed because of the new securities tax touted by government.

fields.title: Winning bid to out auction ghosts
fields.content: The Auction Alliance case of ghost bidders and collusion has confirmed the consumer commission’s powers and capabilities.

fields.title: SA's R100bn industrial action plan
fields.content: The South African government's latest three-year strategy has aimed to boost manufacturing capacity and create jobs but business is sceptical.

fields.title: Yahoo! cuts off 2 000 workers
fields.content: Struggling US internet firm Yahoo! will slash some 2 000 jobs in a sweeping restructuring aimed at building a "nimbler, more profitable" company.

fields.title: Pandor rankled by SKA announcement delay
fields.content: Science and Technology Minister Naledi Pandor is disappointed at the delay of the announcement of whether SA would host the Square Kilometre Array.

fields.title: New labour Bill to curb illegal strikes

fields.title: SA marks 100 days to London Olympics
fields.content: The South African Sports Confederation and Olympic Committee (Sascoc) on Wednesday hosted the celebration of the 100 days-to-go landmark for the 2012 Olympic Games in London.

fields.title: Meyer set to call on Bok old guard
fields.content: Coach Heyneke Meyer has admitted he is considering a number of former and overseas-based Springboks for the series against England.

fields.title: Podium should be possible for Raikkonen
fields.content: Kimi Raikkonen says he'll be racing for a top-three result in Bahrain as long as Lotus are able to get the "upgrades on the car to work properly".

fields.title: Clijsters to miss French Open with hip injury
fields.content: Former world number one Kim Clijsters will miss out on a final chance to claim an elusive French Open title after opting to skip the entire claycourt season due to a hip injury.

fields.title: Chiefs felled again
fields.content: KAIZER Chiefs produced little evidence of a potential new dawn under fresh management last night as they lost a second successive game since firing coach Vladimir Vermezovic.

fields.title: Palacios still chasing his league dream
fields.content: ORLANDO Pirates caretaker coach Augusto Palacios can rightfully look back with pride on his more than 25 years spent as a player and trainer in South Africa, but the one honour that has eluded him is a league title.

fields.title: Cameron flies off to Olympics
fields.content: CAMERON van der Burgh, rated SA swimming's best chance of an Olympic medal in London, cracked the world's third-fastest time of the year as he won the 100m breaststroke at the national championships last night.

fields.title: Bayern set up grand showdown in Madrid

fields.title: Coetzee juggles his injury balls

fields.title: White's rookies take on 'unbeatable' Bulls

fields.title: Bhele rules the roost

fields.title: Chiefs left seeing Stars in Limpopo

fields.title: Magakwe in sprint double

fields.title: A woman's world beckons
fields.content: We are running out of educated men. This is very serious because it impacts on the kind of futures we stand to inherit. And to be blunt, "the future is no longer what it used to be", as the saying goes.

fields.title: SA's electric-car dream dashed

fields.title: SA business to blame for failure in Africa

fields.title: SABMiller 12-month lager volumes up 3%

fields.title: Angloplat March output up 5% year on year

fields.title: Drogba blow stuns Barcelona

fields.title: Rescue likely for Spanish banks

fields.title: Web shops warned to deal with feedback or lose out

Goldstuck was presenting the findings of an online shopping survey at the Mastercard Online Shopping Forum in Johannesburg yesterday.

fields.title: Buffett has cancer, but ‘not life-threatening’
fields.content: Berkshire Hathaway chief executive Warren Buffett had stage 1 prostate cancer, he announced on Tuesday, but he said his condition “is not remotely life-threatening or even debilitating in any meaningful way”.

fields.title: Drillers cause quakes

fields.title: Small-scale farmers are vital link in food security

fields.title: How to cook bugs

fields.title: Seizure adds insult to Spanish woes

fields.title: Mixed signs for rates as inflation falls to 6%

fields.title: Eastern Cape High Court post hopefuls found lacking

fields.title: Umalusi defends 30% matric pass mark

fields.title: NEWS ANALYSIS: Hlophe misconduct hearing must take place

fields.title: Another Week - 20 April 2012

fields.title: Property - Midrand mall race

fields.title:
Telkom 
Department still deciding on KT deal
fields.content: A decision on the sale of a 20 percent stake in Telkom to South Korea’s KT Corporation could be reached by the end of May, Communications Minister Dina Pule said yesterday. Speaking in a briefing on the sidelines of the National Information and Communication Technology Policy Colloquium, Pule said the department had received a “diagnostic analysis” on Telkom and had recently appointed deal advisers to advise on the proposed transaction. “I want to believe that by the end of May and even before the end of May we will have finished,” she said. More than six months have passed since Telkom announced its discussions with KT in October last year. Pule would not be drawn into a discussion on the government’s willingness to dilute its controlling stake in Telkom. She said: “It is inevitable for us to drag it out too long… it involves another country… and it involves my government. I don’t want to take decisions on my own.” Telkom rose 0.35 percent to close at R23.25 yesterday. – Asha Speckman

fields.content: Business Connexion (BCX) was eyeing opportunities in outsourcing, data centres and managed services in Kenya, Ghana and Nigeria, chief executive Benjamin Mophatlane said yesterday. There were significant opportunities for services companies outside of the country, he said. “South Africa is well-established but there are not a lot of services companies in Africa,” he said, without providing a timeframe for the continental expansion. Revenue for the six months to February leapt 43.5 percent to R2.7 billion. – Asha Speckman

fields.title:
Premium 
Rising costs cut distributions
fields.content: Distributions by Premium Properties dropped to R1.158 a linked unit in the year to February from R1.169 in the previous year, despite revenue rising 14.9 percent, the listed property loan stock company reported yesterday. Managing director Jeffrey Wapnick said the second-half performance improved substantially from the first. Wapnick said this was achieved in a difficult trading environment with the total cost of occupation by tenants increasing. The company’s shares fell 1.02 percent to R14.60 yesterday. – Roy Cokayne
